key_points: The US House of Representatives is set to debate an article of impeachment against Donald Trump, accusing him of inciting violence against the US government.
Trump's urging of his supporters to "fight" before the Capitol riot is central to the accusation.
The impeachment process is political, not legal, allowing Congress to determine guilt without proving legal culpability.
67 percent of Americans, according to an ABC News/Ipsos poll, believe Trump deserves blame for the riot.
56 percent of Americans think Trump should be removed from office before the end of his term.
Experts argue the legal bar for proving Trump's guilt in incitement is high.
Jeffrey Scott Shapiro, a former assistant attorney general, believes Trump's speech is protected by the Constitution.
Constitutional law professor Andrew Koppelman states it would be difficult to prove Trump intended for violence to ensue.
Despite impeachment, prosecuting Trump for incitement may face significant hurdles.
Biden is focused on other issues, despite some Democrats' calls for legal action against Trump post-presidency.
spokespersons: Jeffrey Scott Shapiro (former District of Columbia assistant attorney general)
Andrew Koppelman (constitutional law professor, Northwestern University)
